Name: Ophiuchus
Story: The serpent bearer; in Greek mythology, Asclepius, the god of medicine, depicted in the sky holding the snake Serpens.

Name: Scutum
Story: The shield; a constellation honouring King John III Sobieski of Poland – the only politically inspired constellation still in use.

Name: Lupus
Story: The wolf; an ancient constellation, but without mythological association.

Name: Horologium
Story: The pendulum clock; a modern constellation introduced by Lacaille in 1756.

Name: Mensa
Story: Table Mountain, South Africa; a modern constellation introduced by Lacaille in 1756, celebrating his southern-hemisphere observing site.

Name: Indus
Story: The Indian; introduced as a constellation by Keyser & de Houtman in 1598.

Name: Musca
Story: The fly; a constellation introduced by Keyser & de Houtman in 1598.

Name: Pisces
Story: Two fishes, swimming in opposite directions with their tails connected by a cord.

Name: Pegasus
Story: The winged horse; in Greek mythology, used by Zeus to carry thunder and lightning.

Name: Lepus
Story: The hare; often depicted being chased by Orion and his two dogs.

Name: Sagittarius
Story: The archer; usually drawn as a centaur – half man, half horse

Name: Volans
Story: The flying fish; a constellation introduced by Keyser & de Houtman in 1598, celebrating the family Exocoetidae.

Name: Telescopium
Story: The telescope; a modern constellation introduced by Lacaille in 1756.

Name: Tucana
Story: The toucan; a constellation introduced by Keyser & de Houtman in 1598.

Name: Ursa Minor
Story: The lesser bear; in Greek mythology, one of the nymphs that nursed Zeus as an infant.

Name: Ursa Major
Story: The great bear, also known as the Big Dipper or the Plough. In Greek mythology, Callisto, lover of Zeus.

Name: Triangulum
Story: The triangle; appearing similar to a capital delta in the Greek alphabet.

Name: Serpens
Story: The serpent's head; held by Ophiuchus and part of the same constellation as Serpens Cauda. The serpent's tail; held by Ophiuchus and part of the same constellation as Serpens Caput.

Name: Vulpecula
Story: The fox; a constellation introduced by Johannes Hevelius in 1687.

Name: Gemini
Story: The mythical twins Castor and Pollux.

Name: Dorado
Story: The goldfish; a constellation introduced by Keyser & de Houtman in 1598.

Name: Caelum
Story: The chisel; a southern constellation introduced by Lacaille in 1756.

Name: Columba
Story: The dove; introduced by Plancius in 1592. In Biblical history, said to be the dove of Noah.

Name: Grus
Story: The crane; a constellation introduced by Keyser & de Houtman in 1598.

Name: Canis Minor
Story: The lesser dog; in Greek mythology, a hunting dog belonging to Orion, depicted pursuing the hare Lepus.

Name: Equuleus
Story: The little horse; a tiny yet ancient constellation with no mythological association.

Name: Eridanus
Story: The mythical river Eridanus; associated variously with the Nile or Po.

Name: Hercules
Story: Hercules; a large yet dark constellation representing the greatest hero of Greek mythology.

Name: Crux
Story: The southern cross; introduced as a constellation by Plancius in 1598.

Name: Cygnus
Story: The swan; in Greek mythology, Zeus in disguise.

Name: Hydrus
Story: The lesser water snake; introduced as a constellation by Keyser & de Houtman in 1598.

Name: Canes Venatici
Story: The hunting dogs; introduced by Johannes Hevelius in 1687, and said to be held by the herdsman Bootes.

Name: Corona Australis
Story: The southern crown, lying at the feet of Sagittarius, and known to the Greeks as a wreath.

Name: Corona Borealis
Story: The northern crown; in Greek mythology, worn by the Princess Ariadne on her wedding day.

Name: Leo Minor
Story: The lion cub; introduced as a constellation by Johannes Hevelius in 1687.

Name: Lynx
Story: The lynx; a faint constellation introduced by Johannes Hevelius in 1687.

Name: Leo
Story: The lion of Nemea; in Greek mythology, a monster slain by Hercules.

Name: Lyra
Story: The lyre; often said to be played by Orpheus, the greatest musician of his age.

Name: Sculptor
Story: The sculptor – originally, the sculptor's studio; a modern constellation introduced by Lacaille in 1756.

Name: Monoceros
Story: The unicorn; a constellation introduced by Plancius in 1612.

Name: Triangulum Australe
Story: The southern triangle; a constellation introduced by Keyser & de Houtman in 1598.

Name: Microscopium
Story: The microscope; a modern constellation introduced by Lacaille in 1756.

Name: Phoenix
Story: The phoenix; a constellation introduced by Keyser & de Houtman in 1598.

Name: Piscis Austrinus
Story: The southern fish; the parent of the two fish depicted by Pisces.

Name: Virgo
Story: The virgin; in Greek mythology, the goddess of justice.

Name: Sagitta
Story: The arrow; in Greek mythology, perhaps the arrow that Apollo used to kill the Cyclopes.

Name: Perseus
Story: Perseus; in Greek mythology, the husband of Andromeda, also known for slaying Medusa the Gorgon.

Name: Carina
Story: The keel; a sub-division of the ancient constellation Argo – in Greek mythology, the ship of the Argonauts.

Name: Canis Major
Story: The greater dog; in Greek mythology, a hunting dog belonging to Orion, depicted pursuing the hare Lepus.

Name: Auriga
Story: The charioteer; in Greek mythology, Erichthonius, son of Vulcan, the first person to attach four horses to a chariot.

Name: Aquila
Story: The eagle; in Greek mythology, the bird of Zeus and the retriever of his thunderbolts.

Name: Cepheus
Story: King Cepheus of Ethiopeia; in Greek mythology, the king of Ethiopia, descended from Zeus and Io.

Name: Circinus
Story: The pair of dividing compasses; a modern constellation introduced by Lacaille in 1756.

Name: Ara
Story: The altar; in Greek mythology, used by the Gods to vow allegiance before their battle with the Titans.

Name: Camelopardalis
Story: The giraffe; a large but faint northern constellation introduced by Plancius in 1612.

Name: Cetus
Story: The sea monster, which in Greek mythology attacked Cepheus's territory and Andromeda, but which was slain by Perseus.

Name: Coma Berenices
Story: The hair of Queen Berenice of Egypt; introduced as a constellation by Vopel in 1536.

Name: Fornax
Story: The furnace; originally a chemist's distillation furnace, introduced by Lacaille in 1756.

Name: Hydra
Story: The multi-headed water snake, slain by Hercules in Greek mythology.

Name: Libra
Story: The balance; a zodiacal constellation introduced by the Romans.

Name: Crater
Story: The cup; in Greek mythology, clutched by the crow Crater in its search for water.

Name: Lacerta
Story: The lizard; introduced as a constellation by Johannes Hevelius in 1690.

Name: Delphinus
Story: The dolphin; in Greek mythology, the messenger of Poseidon.

Name: Corvus
Story: The crow; in Greek mythology, sent by Apollo in search of water.

Name: Draco
Story: The dragon; in Greek mythology, Ladon, guard of the tree on which golden apples grew, slain by Hercules.

Name: Cancer
Story: The crab; in Greek mythology, a crab which bit Hercules's foot.

Name: Centaurus
Story: The Centaur: half man and half horse; in Greek mythology, the wise centaur Chiron.

Name: Cassiopeia
Story: Queen Cassiopeia; in Greek mythology, wife of Cepheus and mother of Andromeda.

Name: Apus
Story: The bird of paradise; a southern constellation introduced by Keyser & de Houtman in 1598.

Name: Chamaeleon
Story: The chameleon; introduced by Keyser & de Houtman in 1598.

Name: Antlia
Story: The air pump; a southern constellation introduced by Lacaille in 1756, originally the 'pneumatic machine'.

Name: Aquarius
Story: The water bearer; in Greek mythology, Ganymede, wine-waiter to the Gods and lover of Zeus.

Name: Capricornus
Story: The sea goat; associated with Pan in Greek mythology, god of the countryside.

Name: Andromeda
Story: The Princess Andromeda; in Greek mythology, the daughter of Cepheus and Cassiopeia and wife of Perseus.

Name: Bootes
Story: The herdsman; in Greek mythology, Arcas, son of Zeus by Callisto.

Name: Aries
Story: The ram; in Greek mythology, the animal whose golden fleece was recovered by Jason and the Argonauts.

Name: Puppis
Story: The poop deck of the Argo Navis; a sub-division of the ancient constellation Argo – in Greek mythology, the ship of the Argonauts.

Name: Scorpius
Story: The scorpion; said to have stung the hunter Orion to death in Greek mythology.

Name: Orion
Story: The hunter; associated in Greek mythology with a son of Poseidon, but associated by the Sumerians with their great hero Gilgamesh.

Name: Octans
Story: The octant, a navigational instrument invented in the 1730s. A modern constellation introduced by Lacaille in 1756.

Name: Pictor
Story: The painter's easel; a modern constellation introduced by Lacaille in 1756.

Name: Reticulum
Story: The net; a southern constellation introduced by Lacaille in 1756, commemorating the cross-hair in his telescope.

Name: Pyxis
Story: The compass; a southern constellation introduced by Lacaille in 1756.

Name: Norma
Story: The set square; a modern constellation introduced by Lacaille in 1756.

Name: Pavo
Story: The peacock; a constellation introduced by Keyser & de Houtman in 1598.

Name: Sextans
Story: The sextant; a constellation introduced by Johannes Hevelius in 1687, celebrating an instrument used to measure star positions.

Name: Vela
Story: The sail; a sub-division of the ancient constellation Argo – in Greek mythology, the ship of the Argonauts.

Name: Taurus
Story: The bull; said by the Sumerians to be charging at Orion the hunter, but in Greek mythology said to be Zeus in disguise.
